question: What is the structure of Tellurium chloride?

content.source_1: Tellurium tetrachloride Tellurium tetrachloride is the inorganic compound with the empirical formula TeCl. The compound is volatile, subliming at 200 Â°C at 0.1 mmHg. Molten TeCl is ionic, dissociating into TeCl and TeCl. TeCl is monomeric in the gas phase, with a structure similar to that of SF. In the solid state, it is a tetrameric cubane-type cluster, consisting of a TeCl core and three terminal chloride ligands for each Te. Alternatively, this tetrameric structure can be considered as a Te tetrahedron with face-capping chlorines and three terminal chlorines per tellurium atom, giving each tellurium atom a distorted octahedral environment
content.source_2: Tritellurium dichloride Tritellurium dichloride is the inorganic compound with the formula TeCl. It is one of the more stable lower chlorides of tellurium. TeCl is a gray solid. Its structure consists of a long chain of Te atoms, with every third Te center carrying two chloride ligands for the repeat unit -Te-Te-TeCl-. It is a semiconductor with a band gap of 1.52 eV, which is larger than that for elemental Te (0.34 eV). It is prepared by heating Te with the appropriate stoichiometry of chlorine. TeCl is a yellow liquid prepared by reaction of lithium polytellurides with TeCl. TeCl, also

answer: A long chain of Te atoms, with every third Te center carrying two chloride ligands for the repeat unit -Te-Te-TeCl-
